FacilityName: Marine Corps Air Station - Cherry Point

4.1 Executive Summary

MCAS Cherry Point's accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are to maintain safe conditions for base personnel and the inhabitants of the surrounding communities.  This policy is to be enforced through strict compliance with applicable regulations, physical safeguards, rigorous training, and deployment of adequate resources.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response are given the highest priority.

The CAA Amendments of 1990 required the EPA to formulate regulations for managing and reducing the probability of release of highly hazardous chemicals.  On June 20, 1996, EPA promulgated the RMP rule (40 CFR 68) requiring any stationary source utilizing greater than a specified threshold quantity of a regulated substance to develop and submit a RMPlan to regulatory authorities on or before June 21, 1999.  Regulated substances include 77 air toxics and 63 flammable gases or liquids.

MCAS Cherry Point has one process subject to EPA RMP regulations:

A?    Chlorine storage, handling, and use at the WTP

Chlorine is used in excess of their threshold quantities of 2,500 pounds.  Chlorine is stored in one-ton containers and used in the treatment of drinking water at the WTP.  The chlorine is stored under pressure as a liquid in up to four one-ton containers.  Typically, two of the four containers are connected to the chlorine feed system with up to 2 containers in storage.  

This RMPlan summarizes the primary components of the RMP in place at MCAS Cherry Point to correspond with specific EPA RMP requirements, including:

A?    Management - A separate document, the "Compliance Management Plan for Clean Air Act Section 112(r) Risk Management Program" details specific requirements for a management system under 40 CFR 68.15.

A?    Hazard Assessment - The Hazard Assessment evaluated a WCS and ARS with the chlorine storage area considered as mitigation because the area is an enclosed space in direct contact with outside air.  

Inte

rviews with operations, maintenance, and management personnel at MCAS Cherry Point indicated that there have been no accidental releases from the covered processes in the five years prior to conducting this hazard assessment that resulted in any of the regulatory impacts.  In addition, according to personnel at the Air Station, no accidents have ever occurred resulting in this type of damage or human impact.  

The modeling methodology used in this study conforms to the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance recommended in the final RMP rule.  The toxic release scenarios for chlorine were modeled using RMP*CompTM Version 1.07.  

The WCS, as defined in 40 CFR 68.25(2), should be modeled to represent the greatest distance to a toxic endpoint, under worst-case conditions, beyond the stationary source boundary.  The ARS should represent a more likely scenario, under realistic conditions, but should still yield an offsite impact (40 CFR 68.28(b)).

The WCS for the WTP is a catastrophic release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine gas.  This scenario assumed a container valve failure releasing all of the contents of the one-ton container over a 10-minute period.  The chlorine storage area was considered mitigation because the area is an enclosed space in direct contact with outside air.  The distance to toxic endpoint of three parts per million for chlorine was 0.9 miles under worst-case atmospheric conditions.  

The ARS for the WTP modeled the full release of one, one-ton container due to a hole in the container valve and the release rate was assumed to be equal to the release rate for the WCS.  The chlorine storage area was considered mitigation because the area is an enclosed space in direct contact with outside air.  The distance to toxic endpoint of three parts per million for chlorine was 0.5 miles for the alternative scenario.  


A?    Prevention Program 3 - Cherry Point has implemented all elements of Prevention Program 3 and has taken special steps to enclose chl

orine areas and install chlorine monitors to prevent releases.  A brief description of MCAS Cherry Point's compliance with each element follows.

PSI was compiled prior to conducting the PHA.  This compilation of information enables supervisors and employees of covered processes to identify and understand hazards involved in the process.  The PSI compilation includes information on the hazards of the regulated substance, information regarding the technology of the process, and technical information on the equipment in the process.

The PHA update involves the systematic evaluation of the hazards posed by the regulated process.  The What-if Checklist analysis method was selected for analyzing the chlorine systems at the WTP.  The What-if analysis, a technique recognized by EPA, is a brainstorming approach that focuses on potential initiating events and consequences associated with a release.  This technique also allows for examination of current procedures and practices.  The PHA study was performed to identify and document process hazards and preventive and mitigating measures.  

Written Operating Procedures for each covered process were compiled that provide "clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety information" to include the steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.  The Operating Procedures are available to all employees working in the process and must be reviewed annually to ensure currency.  The Operating Procedures for the WTP are a compilation of SOPs, manufacturer operating procedures, and Chlorine Institute operating procedures.

Training in an overview of the process and the operating procedures for each process has been performed for each employee working in or maintaining that process.  This training includes initial and refresher training focusing on safety and health hazards, emergency operat

ions during shutdown, and safe work practices.  

A Mechanical Integrity Program has been developed for the following equipment at the WTP:
A?    Pressurized chlorine containers;
A?    Piping systems (including piping components such as valves);
A?    Relief and vent systems;
A?    Emergency shutdown systems; and
A?    Control measures.

This program includes written procedures and schedules for maintaining the good working order of process equipment, training for all employees performing maintenance on process equipment, regular inspection and testing of process equipment, prompt correction of equipment deficiencies, and appropriate checks and inspections to assure process equipment is of suitable fabrication and quality for its intended purpose.

MCAS Cherry Point has a comprehensive Management of Change procedure in place for all processes subject to the RMP rule to ensure that any changes (except replacements-in-kind) to the process are reviewed prior to being implemented.  The procedure requires review of changes by appropriate supervisory, maintenance, fire department, and environmental personnel for technical basis, impacts on safety and health, and changes to other portions of the RMP for the process. 

A Pre-startup Safety Review will be performed for any covered process anytime the process is modified enough to require a change in PSI.  The Pre-startup Safety Review will confirm construction and design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place; PHA has been performed and resolved; and all employees working in the process have been trained. 

Periodic Compliance Audits will be performed for covered processes to ensure adherence to procedures and practices required by the RMP.  These audits will be performed at least every three years by the Environmental Affairs Department and WTP personnel.  The findings will be reported and actions taken to correct any deficiencies, and the two most recent audits will be retained by the Enviro

nmental Affairs Department. 

An Incident Investigation procedure is in place at MCAS Cherry Point to investigate any incident that resulted in, or could have resulted in catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  This procedure is outlined in OPNAVINST 5100.23E, Chapter 14, Navy Instructions for Mishap Investigation, Reporting, and Recordkeeping.  This procedure will convene a committee consisting of supervisors, an environmental representative, and other process personnel.  This committee will investigate and report the cause of the incident and make recommendations for reducing the probability of such an incident in the future.  Recommendations will be resolved as quickly as possible and the report shall be reviewed with all employees or contractors whose job tasks are relevant to the report findings.

A written Employee Participation Plan has been developed and implemented for covered processes at the Air Station to ensure that employees are included in conducting and developing the PHA and other elements of the RMP.  Additionally, the PHA and other RMP elements are made available to all employees working at the process.

A Hot Work Permit will be obtained from the Fire Department anytime hot work (i.e., welding or brazing) is performed on covered processes.  The permit will document that fire prevention and protection measures have been taken into account prior to the work being performed.   

The process supervisor of the covered process will ensure that any contractor working on the process follows safe work practices and is informed of hazards and safety of the regulated substance and emergency response procedures.  The contractor will ensure that all employees under his care also follow safe practices and are informed of hazards of the regulated substance and emergency response procedures.  

A?    Emergency Response Program - Cherry Point has a detailed ERP for chlorine releases.  Water Treatment Plant personnel are instructed to notify the MCAS Cherry P

oint Fire Department in the event of any accidental releases.  The Fire Department is the first responder in the event of a release - WTP employees do not respond to chlorine releases.  The ERP also includes communication with regulatory and other response agencies as well as first aid information.

The plans also include:
- Documentation of proper first-aid and medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures;
- Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection and testing;
- A description of the training program for all employees in relevant emergency response procedures; and
- Procedures for review and update, as necessary, the ERP to reflect changes at the facility, and to ensure that employees are informed of these changes.

A?    Planned Changes to Improve Safety - Resulting from Cherry Point's most recent PHA (conducted 8/16-17/2010), the WTP plans to investigate options to improve safety, including installing an emergency eyewash in the chlorine cylinder storage room and requesting the Safety Office to conduct a PPE hazard assessment for tasks associated with the chlorine injection system.
